intro: Boechera microphylla var. harrisonii, commonly known as Harrison's rockcress, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, cruciform flowers and distinctive seed pods. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, often in alpine or arid environments. Its leaves are basal, linear to oblanceolate, and often covered in fine hairs. This variety is distinguished by its smaller leaves compared to the typical form of Boechera microphylla.
